review_title: Very Easy and Great for working around classes
job_title: Bowling Alley Attendant in Canyon, TX
pros: The schedule is super flexible as long as you communicate properly and the people are super friendly.
cons: This position is only for students, and you can only work 20 scheduled hours a paycheck.

pros: Decent benefits, healthcare, vacation time
cons: Upper management is running this University into the ground. VPs don't bother learning about the inner workings of their departments, and make major decisions based on guesswork instead of consulting the directions, associate directors, and assistant directors. God forbid you're a woman at WT. This backwoods University treats women like second-class citizens. Even if you get a seat at the table, it is just for show. No boomer man will listen to a word you have to say. Leadership is TOO OLD, and out of touch with what is looking to be a nation-wide shake up for higher education.

pros: Unconditional support provided to successfully finish a research project
cons: extensive time on approvals and procedures

review_title: Lack in diversity, not up to date with technology, does not support faculty scholarship
pros: Campus is quiet and clean, nice weather
cons:
No encouragement or support to uphold academic rigor, students rule.
The standards of teaching are embarrassingly low. Many graduate students who are admitted, do not know basic writing skills and have an extremely low GPA, even below 2.0. Professors are pressured to grant high grades to students regardless of the quality of papers. Good students never attend WT. Only those who are not admitted anywhere else, go to WT. 
There is never a lecture meeting, guest lecturer, or any academic activity on campus. I've never seen a university that discourages research collaboration between faculty members the way they do at WT. I was also shocked to see how little knowledge and interest faculty members and administration have about research, grantsmanship, publications, and intellectual innovation. The motto at WT is "don't bring up innovative ideas, scholarship or project of any kind that may advance society, we do not care, we pretend that we do."

cons: Awful management, Constant responsibility changes, Regular fear of termination on a whim.

pros: Good health care benefits, beautiful campus facilities, good I.T. support, highly-reputable university.  Tuition assistance for full-time staff.  Great climate, within minutes of fantastic Palo Duro Canyon State Park.
cons: Pay at a state-university may not be as good as the private sector, depending upon the field.  Being part of the A&M system means a second level of decision-makers can create stress and bring changes that local administrators may not particularly love.

review_title: Friendly atmosphere is great and the working around your schedule is fantastic
pros: If you're a student it's really convenient to walk or short drive to work. Everyone is really friendly and helpful when needed. They care about students and even work around their class schedules very well. You could even work for an hour and come back due to class.
cons: Opportunities to work are a little low. However since the campus is currently growing fast there are added job opportunities often.

review_title: Overall great place to work if you love working in education
job_title: Scene Shop Foreman in Canyon, TX
pros: Working with students is fun and enriching if you enjoy education, and the Department of Art, Theatre, & Dance is overall a great collaborative team. This position was off in the summers so it is also nice to have a summer break.
cons: Paying for parking permits and finding parking on campus are the biggest down sides to working for the university in my opinion.

pros: This institution has a lot of great people who care a lot about the mission and really believe in what the museum is doing
cons: There are not enough staff to do the work but more work continues to be piled on. It doesn't really help that the administration seems to mention how much is done with so little all the time. Feels like lip service

pros: Benefits, educational scholarship, students  are fun, staff support (if allowed), the campus is beautiful, Starbucks in the JBK, campus activities.
cons: Management is top heavy, the staff gets angry phone calls when students can't reach their Professors,

pros: Great atmosphere, works with classes, very flexible. Good coworkers.
cons: Salary, Salary, Salary. The exact same job position with the same requirements at a company in Amarillo (45 miles away) pays 30k (60%) more per year.

pros: I got a lot of valuble training and experience, through studnet worker trainings and the job in general,  and met a lot of people
cons: Not a lot of job movement or raises, but I have not been here too long

pros: Excellent work environment with strong sense of collegiality and commitment to integrity.  Administration, faculty and staff are dedicated to providing students a positive and affordable education that is top notch.  New StrengthsQuest focus is enabling more employees to excel and grow.
cons: Minimal opportunity to increase salary without changing jobs and/or departments. Increases were typically a percent or two/annually.

pros: You get to choose your own time. You get to help student with problems in the subject you have and you get your own class in the university.
cons: Sometime you stay alone and there are no students to help. You have to take a training course before and while doing the sessions.

job_title: Orientation Leader in Belo Horizonte, Minas Gerais

cons: Requires high energy and long weekends, but the orientations are fun and worth it.

review_title: Great Place for People who Value Free Time
pros: People here are very friendly, great place for people who's life isn't dedicated to work. A.K.A Students, single parents, hobbiest.

cons: The director can be hard at times, and the pay isn't exactly competitive. Nothing to make me reconsider working there though.
